name: Brooklyn Bridge
about: The Brooklyn Bridge is one of the city's great engineering marvels and features one of the worlds most beautiful urban parks. It has a wooden footpath above the automobile traffic that is dedicated for pedestrians and bicyclists. While walking you can see the Statue of Liberty, the South Street Seaport and other NYC bridges.
subways: J,Z,4,5 or 6 to Brooklyn Bridge-City Hall

name: Central Park
about: This park has been shown in numerous motion pictures and wedding videos. It was built to be an oasis among the concrete buildings of the city and functions as one of city's cultural centers. From the recreational activities to walking tours to horse drawn carriages to classical concerts, there's always something happening in Central Park.
address: Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60th Street, New York, NY 10022
subways: 2,3 to Central Park North/110th Street; B,C to 110th street, 103rd street, 96th street, 86th street, 81st street, and 72nd street; N,Q or R to 59th Street; A,B,C,D or 1 to 59th street/Columbus Circle

name: Empire State Bldg
about: Named as one of the seven wonders of the world by the ASCE, the Empire State building features 2 observation decks on the 86th and 102nd floors. When the sky is clear one can see New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania and Massachusetts. ABC, CBS and NBC all broadcast from this iconic landmark. The last elevator goes up at 1:15am.
subways: 1,2 or 3 to Penn Station/34th Street; B,D,F,M,N,Q or R to 34th Street/Herald Square

name: Grand Central
about: Grand Central Terminal (more commonly known as Grand Central Station) is the epicenter of NYC transportation with 44 train tracks. It was built in 1871 and has undergone renovations in 1998 and 2007. There are numerous shops, restaurants and calendared events. Nearly 250,000 commuters pass through everyday.
subways: 4,5,6,7 or S to Grand Central/42nd Street

name: High Line
about: Nestled over Chelsea and Hells Kitchen the High Line is an abandoned elevated freight railway that has been turned into a park. The first section was opened in 2009 and now attracts over 5 million visitors each year. It is maintained by a non-profit conservancy (Friends of the High Line) in conjunction with the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation.
hours: Dec 1 - Mar 31 from 7am to 7pm; Apr 1 - May 31 from 7am to 10pm; June 1 - Sept 30 from 7am to 11pm; Oct 1 - Nov 30 from 7am to 10:00pm
subways: A,C,E or L to 14th Street (southernmost entrace); 7 to 34th Street - Hudson Yards (northernmost entrance)

name: The Met
about: It's easy to get lost among the maze of galleries in the largest museum NYC has to offer. The 'Met' as it's commonly called, features over 2 million pieces from all over the globe divided into 17 curatorial departments. The roof garden exhibits works and sculptures by contemporary artists. There is also a cafe and martini bar where people can sit an enjoy views of Central Park.
address: 1000 Fifth Avenue, New York, New York 10028
hours: Sunday - Thursday from 10am to 5:30 pm; Friday and Saturday from 10am to 9pm

about: Located at the World Trade Center, the 9/11 Memorial and Memorial Museum are built to commemorate the September 11, 2001 attacks and the World Trade Center bombing of February 26, 1993. The memorial is field of white oaks with 2 reflecting pools that sit in the footprints of the Twin Towers. The Memorial Museum is located below street level and was dedicated on May 15, 2014.
hours: Memorial: Daily from 7:30am to 9pm. Museum: Sun - Thurs from 9am to 8pm and Fri - Sat from 9am to 9pm
subways: 2,3 to Park Place; A,C,J,2,3,4 or 5 to Fulton Street

name: Rockefeller
about: No matter whether it's Radio City Music Hall, the Top of the Rock, or the ice rink there's no shortage of places to see at the Rockefeller Center. At the center is 30 Rockefeller Plaza were you can find the headquarters for NBC and the famous Rainbow Room restaurant. Each year the iconic Christmas tree is lit as an international symbol for the holidays. Built in the Art Deco design style Rockefeller Center has 19 separate buildings divided into 2 complexes.
hours: Center plaza and concourse: Mon - Fri from 7am to 12am; Top of the Rock: daily from 8am to Midnight (last elevator goes up at 11pm); Ice Rink: October - April, daily from 8:30am to Midnight
subways: B,D,F or M to Rockefeller 47-50th Streets

name: Statue of Liberty
about: As a gift from France to the United States, the Statue of Liberty was dedicated on October 28, 1886 and is located on Liberty Island. Designated as a National Monument in October 1924 it is made of pure copper sheeting over an iron infrastructure. The tablet bears the words 'JULY IV MDCCLXXVI (July 4, 1776)' to commemorate the United States Declaration of Independence. It's estimated the nearly 4 million people visit this iconic monumnent each year.
address: Liberty Island, New York City, NY 10004
subways: 1,R or W to South Ferry. Then take Battery Park Ferry from Battery Park; also Liberty State Park Ferry from Jersey City, NJ

name: Times Square
about: Characterized by the massive digital signs and billboards it was formerly named Longacre Square until 1904 when the New York Times headquarters moved into the area. Times Square includes numerous Broadway theaters, the Diamond District, the Fur District and the affluent Fifth Avenue neighborhood. It is estimated there are around 350,000 visitors each day and nearly 1 million people gather on New Year's Eve for the ball drop.
address: 1560 Broadway #800, New York, NY 10036 (Times Square Alliance)
subways: N,Q,R,S,1,2,3 or 7 to Times Square-42nd Street
